title: Project description
text: Nucleotides can be described by 7 torsional angles and 2 pseudo-torsional angles

title: Project description
text:
RNA torsional angles






Note




Predicting torsional and/or pseudo-torsional angles could help to resolve 3D conformational folding
For each nucleotide, we could angles instead of positions

title: Project description
text:
SPOT-RNA-1D



Network architecture of SPOT-RNA-1D (Singh et al. (2021))



Predict torsional and pseudo-torsional angles from the sequence







Limits




Results fall short of expectations
Neural network architecture could be improved for sequential data
Is the regression the best method ?

title: Project description
text:
RNA torsional angles



Torsional angles distribution on test sets of SPOT-RNA-1D








Goal




Given groups of 2/3, the aim of the project is to predict one torsional/pseudo-torsional angle per nucleotide
The question to be answered: Is classification better than regression for this task ?
Instead of doing regression, the aim would be to try a deep learning architecture for:

Binary classification
Multiclass

The deep learning architecture doesn’t have to be complex (an RNN is sufficient)
You should compare the results of the classification to SPOT-RNA-1D results




Dataset
The datasets are available in the skeleton code available at this link.

Training set: dataset from rsRNASP (Tan et al. (2022)) (192 non-redundant RNAs)
Test set: RNA Puzzles (Cruz et al. (2012)) (29 RNAs)

You should only consider chain A when this is a multi-stranded RNA.


Metrics
The metric to compare the performances is the (Mean Absolute Error).

Mean absolute Error (MAE)


\[
MAE = \min(d_i, 360-d_i)
\]
with: \[
d_i = | angle_i^{pred} - angle_i^{true} |
\]

title: Project guideline
text:
Deliverable




Source code (in Github, Gitlab) (Wednesday, January, 10th. 23h59)
Presentation of 10 min (Friday, January, 12th)









More details




You should send a mail before Wednesday, January, 10th at clement.bernard@univ-evry.fr with object "M2-GENIOMHE Project - GROUP X" (with X your group number)
You have to send the presentation the day before the oral (Thursday, January, 11th)

title: Project guideline
text:
Group
Please create your group and complete the following document.

title: Project guideline
text:
Source code
The source code should have the following requirements:

Have a README to explain how is structured the codes, the installation requirements.
Have a class that can predict the angles from a .fasta file (use the following skeleton)

You can (recommended) start your code from the following link. It provides the basic skeleton for your project, such as the training and testing data.
Your code should include a file with this interface:

class AngleHelper:
  def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
    # TO BE COMPLETE
    pass


  def predict(self, in_path, out_path):
    """
    Function that should predict the angles for the sequence of nucleotides
    Args:
      - in_path: path to a `fasta` file. 
        Example: 
          "
          >17EP
          ACGUUCU
          "
      - out_path: path to a `.json` file where will be stored the prediciton. 
        It should have the following keys: (example with `alpha` angle)
          {
            "17EP": {
              "sequence": "ACGUUCU",
              "angles": {"alpha": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]}
            } 

          }
    """
    return None

Detail the group contribution
